Something that might be of note regarding the "slag" that gets scraped from the top of the bismuth melt. Bismuth is one of very few materials that is less dense in solid form than its melt, meaning solid bismuth floats in liquid bismuth. We did an experiment where we grew bismuth crystals in a way that took advantage of this property. If you heat a container of bismuth (or bismuth shot as we used) to just a little over bismuth's melting point, you can "pull" crystals from the melt by dipping a wire (with a seed crystal of bismuth if you want) into the film on top of the melt and slowly lowering the container by a jack. Lowering it very slowly, you actually get some relatively nice looking crystals forming on the underside while the topside will just look like gray nothing. Bismuth being less dense than its melt may also have contributed to how long it took for your crude chunks to melt. Once there was enough liquid, the remaining solid would just float and have a protective barrier of liquid bismuth insulating it from further heating.

In ceramics when we make crystal glazed items we have to active cool the kilns. That is, usually, we put in a heating program, and once its done, the kiln is shut off and allowed to cool slowly just under its own insulation. With active cooling though, instead of turning the kiln off, you put in a new program that slowly ramps the heat down. So the elements are on, and heating during the entire crystal formation, just at a lesser rate than before. It gives a lot of control and ability to watch the crystals for as you like.

In certainly not a chemist, so I might be missing something but there are a few tricks to heating things up without oxidizing them. There are kilns and furnaces, and in fact kits to convert them, which trickle in argon to displace the oxygen. Another trick is to use a sealed container, like a thin steel envelope, into which you could put something flammable, like wood or paper, as well as what you're trying to heat up. The idea is that itll burn and use up all the oxygen.

Fun fact about bismuth: it's actually radioactive, except not really. The most common isotope of bismuth, Bi-209, had long been suspected of being radioactive, but this wasn't confirmed until 2007, when a single Bi-209 atom was observed emitting an alpha particle. The half-life of Bi-209 is estimated to be about 2.01×10^19 years, longer by several orders of magnitude than the estimated age of the universe. In other words, for all intents and purposes it's a stable element.

I just did this experiment with my girlfriend to get her more interested in science, I followed your directions mostly and it worked out pretty decent. I made sure to check the ingredients throughly beforehand and we went with the pill form which it looks like you used in the previous video. They were also only about 2$ per 40 pills so we did 5 bottles of them. The pills were more concentrated and probably did not have the same amount of base in them so I went with my gut on the amount of acid/water but I think I over did it a bit. Our reaction was clearly quite exothermic once we added the foil into it as opposed to the more gentle bubbling you had but we did it outside with proper safety equipment so it was honestly the one part my girlfriend actually liked as it made her feel like a witch. I didn’t bore her with any calculations so I don’t have a percent yield but it was clearly working quite well and I’m sure she will get a decent small chunk of bismuth from all of the powder that she can say she made herself.

You really need a centrifuge for stuff like this .. hand operated ones are quite affordable. They wouldn't help you separate stuff like proteins, but it'd deffy help with stuff like the salicylic acid. The gelatinated starch you can lose by heating the stuff up and cooling it back down, letting it sit for 24+ hrs. It re-gels into larger chunks that are more difficult to filter without losing product, but easier to centrifuge with a hand operated centrifuge with little loss in product.

Metalsmiths use flux to prevent oxidation of metals during smelting and metal casting.  Often, we use borax soap which "melts" along with the metal and covers the top.  When poured, the flux floats to the top of the metal and is easily removed by grinding.  Historically, everything from noble gasses to sand has been used to block heated metal from oxidizing air.  Using a ceramic crucible also helps with heat retention and even heating.  Direct heating from the top of the metal also helps to "push" any present air away from the surface of the metal.  Using a kiln can also help with even heating and crucibles can be "sealed" to help with oxidation.

The best part...even though it seems stable, even to a geiger counter, bismuth is technically radioactive. Bismuth 209 was long thought to be radioactive on purely mathematical grounds, but no radioactivity was ever observed from it. It was eventually determined that it IS radioactive, but its half life is almost 20 quintillion years. It would be very difficult to detect any radioactivity from it, since decay events happen so infrequently (it's WAAAAAY below natural background). It decays to thallium 205 via alpha decay.

Hi, interesting video. I had an idea you may or may not be interested in. It might not be worth the time and effort, its up to you. Its about the pepto tablet you tried to mold. I do a lot of bullet molding and you may get better results with the mold if you heat the mold to the melting point of the bismuth if that even possible. I know when melting lead to make bullets, if the mold is too cold you'll get very poor bullets. What happens when it's too cold is as you poor in the molten metal to the cold mold, it solidifies unevenly and you get poor results. If the mold is hot, it may solidify more evenly as it cools and it might make a tablet a little closer to perfect. It may or may not work with bismuth but it does with lead. Good luck!

This is a lesson in quantities and why often in a lab you use small amounts of reagents. Smaller amounts of reagents react more completely than large amounts with less complication. Filters are not blocked, precipitates are completed, and you can titrate acid instead of dumping incredibly dangerous amounts.

Acid is highly reactive, and I'm sure you don't have an emergency shower in your demonstration area you can pull in case of an emergency such as dumping it all over yourself.

There is reason why you use a hood, and there is a reason it has a see - through door to lower in front of your activities. You wore goggles, right? Right?

Also, a hood door is explosion - proof in case of mishaps. And there is no floor inside for reagents to spill.

I would like to see some neoprene gloves on those hands. And using smaller quantities of acid and water would reduce the danger as well.

Perhaps a few layers of cheesecloth could help filter out the starch on the first, maybe second filtrations and allow the solution to pass through without clogging. Then once the worst part of the starch is gone, using coffee filters and then laboratory filters would go quicker.

You can use an inert gas such as either nitrogen or argon to prevent oxidization. The use of nitrogen would require more advanced, and expensive, equipment so I would recommend argon. Additionally, argon is more dense than oxygen allowing it to be pumped into the glass vessel to create a "bath". I would use fine mesh quick casting sand for both growing crystals and, of course, casts. You can change the cooling times by running either pipes or heating elements dependent on which way you would like the temperature to go. For crystals it is best to make sure a seed or a lattice is present for the structure to grow upon. Best of luck!

One thing you can do to prevent the oxide from developing on the bismuth is by covering your test tube with foil tape on top and punch 2 holes in the tape. Get a tank of helium or argon gas(you can rent one from a welding supply store) and run a small gas hose from the valve to one of the wholes wile leaving the other whole open(make sure to tape the hose in place). You might want to get some copper tubing to run from the rubber gas hose to the foil tape to prevent melting the hose. The open hole should be smaller because it only acts as a vent. Now turn the valve on from the bottle of helium to about 5 pounds. This will continually purge all oxygen out of the test tube wile you heat it up. No oxygen, = no oxidization.😎 Oh, and that will prevent any flaming on the inside of the beaker as well of course. Please send me a reply to let me know if this helped. Thnx. 😁 Now, I'm not sure if the copper tubing would react badly with the chemical fumes coming off the bismuth as you heat it up but if so then you might want to use stainless tubing instead. Thought I would mention that just in case suggesting copper tubing would be a bad idea.
I was a welder and I would use this method to TIG weld two pieces of stainless pipe together which leaves a nice smooth weld on the inside for sanitary purposes so that you can run food grade liquid through it like milk at a dairy farm.

What brought light to her case was the fact that when they first took a few blood samples from her, it crystalized the moment it made it's way into the syringe. It was suspected that the hospital have pumped different kinds of chemicals into her, hoping to make clear of the symptoms of her unusual case without closely inspecting her medical history and pharmaceutical purchases. I have done a fair amount of lost wax casting so I am decently familiar with melting metal. If you try melting Bismuth or any other metal again, look into something called flux. It is a chemical you add to minimize oxide formation. As an example, when I would cast in copper, bronze or silver, I would add Borax to the metal as I was melting it. The resulting slag/scale form on the outside of the final cast piece and would be removed using a mild acid (pool shock acid). I am sure that there is some equivalent chemical that you can use as a flux for melting and casting Bismuth.

I used to make bismuth crystal jewellery, and in amounts not much larger than this - maybe 50g or so per time. Unlike a metal crucible however, I bought some cheap graphite ones which not only contain the heat better, but also help to reduce a bit of the oxide slag (still plenty to skim off though). Simply stood the crucible on a tolerable metal surface that could be sacrificed, and hit with a blowtorch until the bismuth all melted - even a cremé brûlée type worked (albeit I used the Dremel VersaFlame).

To make the jewellery, I inserted 14-19 gauge pure copper wire (don’t get it from electronics due to the insulator coating) for a couple of minutes until the surface had been getting hard for 10-15 seconds. Then the wire is removed and you have a couple of larger crystals or lots of smaller ones depending on whether the wire was disturbed much or not. The wire is then looped and twisted at the top of the crystal, the excess cut off, and you have a really awesome amulet.

Another thing I found was that the older the bismuth, the darker the colours. Initially you get really bright blues, reds, and sometimes greens, however when remelted several times, the colours tended to go to dark blue, purple, and gold. I’m guessing small amounts of oxide get incorporated into the bulk metal in minute quantities, and migrate to the surface where it combines with fresh oxide film. Awesome stuff either way and was really fun.

ingredients
10 grams zinc powder
10 grams copper sulphate
2 ml sulphuric acid
3 grains of calcium metal


procedure place copper sulphate in a 100ml beaker and add 2 ml sulphuric acid allow to mix for at least 4 minutes (do not heat)
then slowly add the zinc powder until the fizzing has died down , let this stand for 3 minutes, now add the 3 grains of calcium to the beaker let this rest after a while and if everything was done correct you should hear a clicking sound similar to a pencil tapping glass, there should be now 2 separate components a liquid which can be filtered off and a solid which is brownish in colour . can you identify what this compound is and why it only clicks in glass?

Nice video!  You should go over some of the safety issues with adding concentrated acid to water though for anyone playing along at home, though!  For anyone reading this, the basic danger is that diluting an acid into water can release a surprising amount of thermal energy.  Diluting sulfuric acid is particularly exothermic.  For this reason you should always acid to water and not the other way around, otherwise enough thermal energy is absorbed by the water to boil it and you can actually get a steam explosion that sprays acid everywhere.  Not fun!  It's also important to pour the acid down a pyrex stirring rod and to go slooooow, giving the water a chance to spread and dissipate the heat.  Water is particularly good at holding onto thermal energy so this can take quite a while.

Interestingly, I just learned that there is no isotope of bismuth that isn't radioactive. Although the most stable isotope, bismuth-209 is pretty much considered stable because its half life is 2.01*10^19 years. Or 20,100,000,000,000,000,000 years. Which, incidentally is more than a billion times longer than the universe has existed.

So if you had a gram of pure bismuth-209, it would take that long for 0.5g of it to decay by emitting radiation, or twice as long for 0.75g of it to do the same.
pepto bismuth...

Here's an idea. I did this experiment using a metal ladle. It doesn't break like glass or ceramic will under immediate heat contact and is larger than the 5 mL teaspoon you're using. When making bismuth crystals you want a deeper utensil or container for bigger, better crystals. Also, to make the colors of the crystals prettier, remove the oxides off the top of the bismuth as it's melting and once or twice as it's cooling (I personally used a fork I wasn't planning on keeping after the experiment). When pouring out the remaining liquid bismuth, the oxides (or slag) falls on the crystals below and sticks to them and coats them with that unappealing silver/gold color. Next, make sure when you're cooling the bismuth down that you hold it very still (movement can dislodge crystals that haven't fully formed yet or disfigure not fully-hardened crystals). If you want reds, oranges, or yellows in your bismuth crystals, you must make sure that the bismuth crystals cool very slowly (especially after you pour out the liquid bismuth). Last thing, the best crystals form after using fresh, unmelted bismuth. I found that remelting the bismuth time after time provided me with some pretty sorry-looking specimens. Hope this gives you some ideas if you ever try this awesome experiment again!!!!

The easiest way to remove those solids from the surface is to skim them off with a spoon.. I make herbal preparations and have the same problem with filters.. I find it's best to let the stuff settle for several hours then gently pour off the liquid.. When it gets low and the solids start moving, I stop.. I then have a fairly pure liquid in one container and solids in another.. Then I make a filter big enough to hold the solids and slowly pour the solids into it.. Stop when the heavy solids start flowing..At this point I set the second filter aside for several hours until the liquid stops dripping through the filter.. I then bottle the clear liquid..

EDIT: some quick "back of an envelope calculations" I forgot to add previous time:
Pepto-Bismol syrup, containing 230 ml at 17.6 mg/ml of C7H5BiO4 (m.m. = 342 amu, of which Bi = 58%) works out to 2.34784 g of Bi per bottle.
Stomach Relief Chewable Tablets, containing 48 tabl. @ 0.2 g of C7H5BiO4/ tabl. works out to the total of 7.29408 g of Bi per packet.
A packet of DEVROM Internal Deodorant (oh, what a name!), containing 100 tablets @ 0,2 g of C7H5BiO6 (m.m. = 394 amu, of which Bi = 53%) yields 10.609137 g Bi.

This is the first of your videos I've seen. You're clearly bright, inquisitive and methodical. My first first-pass criticism is that, LIKE ME, you are far too verbose. In my opinion, you could have condensed down this video by 27-and-a-half minutes without losing any of the flavor of the video, passing along all of the lessons you learned from this project. My second (and final) first-pass criticism should resonate with what you yourself stated at the end of the video, which is that you didn't really know where this project was going from the outset, and the criticism itself is this: Set specific goals at the outset — or ask a specific question you're trying to answer — before setting out toward the store. I'm not trying to be harsh or discouraging; on the contrary, I'm giving you advice on how to keep people like me engaged throughout the entirety of a video.

I figure the little CO2 bubbles were sort of adsorbed onto the microparticles of salicylic acid, at some buoyancy equilibrium where they will neither sink nor let go of the bubble and so will just sit there as a foamy top layer. I watched this zone establish itself numerous times with crushed aluminum-gallium amalgam in water w/ H2 gas, and light but sharp taps caused little clouds to settle out.
I see videos of so many experiments and so often wish I could see what happens if you slapped an ultrasonic transducer on the vessels. I use sonicators at work all the time, and they are excellent at pulling apart granular things like those tablets and popping foamy bubbles. I don't understand why they're not applied more. I swear they'd make boiling chips obsolete also.

Crush the pills in a ball mill,
dissolve the pills in distilled water so it remains pink,
slowly and the HCl until the liquid becomes clear removing the foam to a separate container for washing to increase our yield.

Maybe use a bit of a base to shift the solution back to its pink buffered state and amylase could be used to breakdown the starch. Iodine could be used to test small samples of the solution for complete digestion of the starch. Then add enough HCl to shift it to clear, filter, wash the waste with dilute HCl, not water, to dissolve bismuth still present in the waste. Filter again and add a small sample to a basic solution to see if the pH indicator is still present and another to iodine to check for starch.

I think a good project would be making polysulfide plastics as per the 'inverse vulcanisation' reviewed in this paper https://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlepdf/2017/gc/c7gc00014f. I attended a seminar dealing with this work: the synthesis is remarkably simple and can be done with very easily available reagents. Many different carbon compounds can be used as 'crosslinkers' between the polysulfide chains, leading to polymers with a variety of properties- notably, you can prepare such polymers from plant triglycerides such as olive oil. They're also great at cleaning up heavy metals and I've since attended another seminar in which a composite of these materials and activated carbon was used for cleaning up persistent organic pollutants.

@NileRed could you try mixing your bismuth powder with powdered charcoal when it's wet, making that into a ball before melting it? This would reduce the oxide, giving you pure metal. It would also, of course, produce carbon monoxide gas, so you'd need to do it in a well-ventilated place (like with extractor fans or outside) and take suitable precautions for carbon monoxide. Carbon monoxide can make you go unconscious and then kill you, but in small amounts, I'd personally worry much more about breathing metal vapour which causes permanent damage to your lungs.

You can get near-perfect details casting bismuth in molds made of aluminum foil. Cover the face of the pill with the shiny side to the pill, and wrap it up the sides tightly, then use the eraser on a pencil to burnish the foil on the face and sides until it looks like the pill with a thin coat of aluminum. Then trim the foil around the back edge of the pill to carefully remove the pill from the delicate mold. Pour the bismuth. The face of the resulting bismuth will have a finish as shiny as the aluminum was with great detail.

Very interesting! Let me help you with filtering. .........
Use your glass frit filter as a support for other, stirrable, filter media. Get "fine" and "super fine" washed sand at your big box hardware store. ...........
Fill the volume above the glass frit 50% with the courser sand, and pour your liquid through it. As it clogs, stir the surface with your stirring rod. When you are almost stirring down to the glass, stop, throw out the sand and "stuff", and complete with more sand. ...........
Then, do samo-samo with the fine sand. ...........
Then, at your pool supply store, get some DE replacement, "Fiber Clear". Follow the above technique with that........End result? Crystal clear filtrate...

If you set some of the water aside and subtracted that from your HCL solution, you could have used a spray bottle to knock down the foam from time to time. Now as far as the filler, the best way to filter is to use a two element filter. One normal filter paper with a paper towel, much like the trifold type seen in dispensers, on the dirty side of the filtering device. I work with a lot of precious metal refining projects and sometimes solid hydroxides and chlorides can form and create a hazy suspension which would not go away. The two element filter works wonders. As a contrast, even using 2, 3, 4, or more layers of the same type filter papers would still leave a hazy fluid. Now, melting the bismuth could have gone better. One suggestion would be to combine the bismuth with borax and lead oxide, then melt it. The lead oxide will turn to a lead/bismuth alloy. Once this is done you can fire it in a bone ash dish where the lead would oxidize under the flame (also taking any oxygen which might oxidize the bismuth) and it would be absorbed by the calcium carbonate (bone ash) in the dish/crucible. What you would be left with would be more or less pure bismuth. Another way would be to melt it using an induction furnace in a closed container with an inert gas (argon being the best). But I doubt you would want to spend the time and money to make/buy an induction melting setup for what you are doing. Although bismuth melts at a much lower temperature, it does have some things in common with palladium in that it tends to absorb certain gasses (palladium stores vast ammounts of hydrogen for example and upon poring a melt in open air expands like a magic snake absorbing mostly hydrogen and some oxygen). Recovering and refining metals is one science, but smelting is another.

The USA used to have a very effective natural home treatment for diarrhea called Kaopectate. The active ingredients were white clay (kaolin) and a gel (pectin). Suddenly some obscure doctor got a monograph published that claimed that Kaopectate was not effective. Never mind that it wasn't true and was based on only one small patient sample, it caused the pharmaceutical industry and the FDA to overreact and ban Kaopectate.

To satisfy public demand, the manufacturer created a new Kaopectate containing a different chemical. It was completely ineffective, so a few months later they created still another Kaopectate, this time containing "pink stuff" (bismuth subsalicylate). This chemical also seems to have no effect (other than to create black stool), but nobody seems to care anymore, and the formula will never be changed back. Note that it is easy to buy kaolin and pectin on the Web very cheaply and make your own effective kaopectate!

Fill a beaker with argon, place the bismuth in the beaker and place the beaker in a heated oven, you can even use a toaster oven for small amounts of Bismuth like this.  You can have the oven between 400 and 500 degrees F depending on how big you want the crystals, torch the stuff to a liquid, close the oven door and let it cool VERY slowly...  (I like 500 F but this takes several hours)  WALLAH beautiful bismuth crystals :)

How well does bismuth bond to other metals? The consistency and how it's sticking to the glass makes me think this stuff would be pretty darn useful in making mass produced ballistic plates.

In ballistics armor plates for infantry there are two main methods for preventing over penetration, having a strong enough thick enough mean enough chunk of armor plate and the alternative is to use hard brittle things to stop a few bullets at a much lower weight class by stealing ballistic energy from the bullet by diverting it's penetrative force into shattering a hard material, AR 500 steel plates seem to be in favor now with many people but ceramic composite plate technology is still in use. some time ago a chrome based brittle plate was tested on demolition ranch and it shocked everybody because it had both properties in spades and stopped way more large caliber bullets than a normal ceramic composite plate.

My thinking is that you could make a multi-layer composite plate and use the bismuth as a glue to bond the steel plates together, the bismuth being somewhat brittle is actually a good thing here because it will pull a bunch of kinetic energy out of the system if a high power projectile hits a plate. the difference in melting points of tool steel and bismuth being so different means that you could probably melt the bismuth by running current into the steel or using induction heating while they are already touching, another method would be painting on the bismuth in layers.

You didn't mention it in the video, and this is probably not a 'try-it-at-home' type video, but ALWAYS add acid to water, never water to acid. Strong acids give off heat when dissolving, so if you add the water to the acid, the first little bit of water has a chance to boil and throw concentrated acid everywhere. Needless to say, you don't want this to happen.

Why didn't you use a a nitrogen atmosphere? Heck, you could have gotten away with a carbon dioxide atmosphere which is incredibly easy for a home-brew chemist to make. Pop down to the local King Supers, ask for a block of dry ice, add the dry ice to a stoppered vacuum flask which then vents into the melting vial. The gas is cold but not cold enough to affect melting, you don't have to deal with oxidation at all, and it's cheap. You can get pounds of dry ice for a few bucks.

What you need is an inert-gas or vacuum tube furnace, which are not very expensive (about $2500 new) and can be gotten surplus for a few hundred dollars. These are incredibly useful devices, and you will find many applications that can use it. In the video, I forgot to explain why I chose not to use an inert gas, but there were a couple reasons.


1) When I plan my projects, I try to make them as "simple" as possible, i.e. by doing it in the fewest number of steps and with the least amount of equipment. I find that there is a challenge in doing it like this and I like the creativity that it sometimes requires. If it works (gives the same or similar results), it also optimizes the process and makes it more efficient.


So in this case, I wanted to come up with a way to do it without nitrogen or another inert gas.


2) If I used the gas at the beginning, the water vapor would have just pushed it out anyway. This would leave me with 2 options.


a) Add the gas after the water was gone, but at that point it wouldn't be worth it because most of the bismuth would already be melted or condensed. I would only be preventing a small amount of surface oxidation.


b) dry the bismuth powder and remove all the water first. The problem with that is there would be air mixed in with the powder that would immediately react with it. So, I would have to do a few cycles of vacuum/nitrogen pumping to get it all out.


Between these two options, B is the more "proper" one, but its more work. I would also have to do it in something else, like a round bottom, that might potentially be destroyed. In my opinion, it was much better to do it in a disposable test tube, which required nothing more than a blowtorch and it let me skip a proper drying step. The oxidation was actually still minimal. The first one I did was good, I just didnt melt it enough in the second batch. Nitrogen or argon wouldn't have prevented that either.


EDIT: I also didn't try flux, because on a small scale test the bismuth didn't come together. However, on this larger (but still small) scale, boric acid probably could've worked if I dried the bismuth.

Bismuth and glass have some very interesting interactions producing incredible iridescent effects when added to the glass mixture as a nitrate and reduced around 800c. It's also sometimes used as a non toxic substitute for lead in glass making.


I've been experimenting with developing ceramic glazes containing bismuth compounds and could be worth playing around with if you want to do something interesting with the bismuth you've collected.


Currently the best results to produce iridescence begins by taking a high alkaline Ferro Frit 3110/4110, adding 4% additional 200mesh silica, 6% Kaolin, adding some colourants such as cobalt oxide, copper oxide and even silver nitate and bismuth nitrate between 1-4% of each, producing very different results depending on the ratios of the colourants.


The busmith I think is Bismuth(III) nitrate pentahydrate, I made it by dissolving a chunk of bismuth in nitric acid, drying and recovering the crystals. Silver nitate was produced the same way but with silver instead, the nitate salts are needed so they can be dissolved in water and properly dispersed with the glass mixture.


Everything is dissolved in water and painted on bisque ceramics and fired to 1060c to form the glass. When it comes out, it looks really boring like nothing has happened. I then take the kiln to 800c at which point I remove as much oxygen from the kiln as possible using LPG vented in via a bunsen burner with the vents closed through one of the spy holes, the kiln is turned off but the gas is still reducing the atmosphere and I let it run for about half an hour, the temperature usually reduces a hundred degrees. Through this the glass is soft and the removal of the oxygen in the atmosphere reduces the metals in the glass mixture, causing nanoscopic beads of metal to pool at the top layer of the glass. At least this is my guess and seems to be shown from the handful of papers I could find which scanned similar results under an electron microscope.


This ends up creating stunning lustre/iridescent effects as you would find on butterfly wings. Bismuth creates its characteristic rainbow effects, silver creates cyan blues and purples similar to butterfly wings, copper goes from red through to metallic copper and cobalt produces intense blues and purples.


This produces lustre ceramics and some pretty wonderful effects. If you ever get access to a kiln that can handle those temperatures and can produce a reducing atmosphere, it might be fun to play around with to get iridescent glass.

I want to play around with bismuth, but I don't have the equipment for testing the ideas I have.
But, the oxide layer is thinner in faster cooling and thicker in slower cooling. I've noticed that a lot of the molded sculptures have bands of color. This makes me think that a tool is being used to keep those bands at a warmer temp while the oxide forms, producing the band of that color, and possibly a gradient between the warmer and cooler sections.
I'm thinking that it's a cast with heater rings around it. If the cast has enough heat permeability, or even direct transferability, you should be able to pour the mold but keep rings of it hotter than others, producing the rainbow-like gradient. Inversely, insulation could also work, but I think heating would be more controllable. I've read that the rainbow-like coloring on crystals also depends on the mass of the crystal itself, where a larger internal mass will cause slower oxidation.
I've also read that the colors roughly follow the electromagnetic spectrum, where thinnest is violet and thickest is red. This makes me question if bismuth oxide also reaches into IR and UV, I have yet to see testing of this, though.

Don't get me wrong here. You are brilliant, and your videos demonstrate how patient and smart you are when it comes to chemistry. But I will kindly say, you need to study up on working with metal. Having a solid knowledge of chemistry isn't as universal when you start to experiment with other mediums, because you need to have a very solid understanding of how these materials behave under all sorts of different circumstances. Which will absolutely come with time and experience, so don't be discouraged. I did notice quite a few things you did that had clear and dramatic effect on your yields and results. Here's some tips based on my own experience. Try melting the metal under an inert gas, or a vacuum, after you drive off as much water as possible without oxidizing it too bad. A vacuum will lower the melting point, and keep away anything that reacts with it, including water. But use a vacuum with caution, because I have never melted bismuth under one, and I have no idea what all will happen. Nitrogen or argon will work best I think. For making a plaster mold, you 100% NEED to make it a liquid. Not a paste. I'm actually kind of surprised that the mold didn't crack on you, or cause a more violent steam explosion. But this is probably because it was a one sided mold, and not an internal three dimensional one. Next time, make a nice syrup thick plaster slurry. Take your tablet and glue it to a board, tape or glue a round open cookie cutter around it (or any open circle made of metal sheet), and pour the plaster over it. Let it dry completely before you break it out, and never ever wash the mold with water. This is why you didn't capture any detail. Use a brush very carefully to remove any excess material, but remember how delicate the mold is. Drive off the moisture with your oven, but cast the metal right when you take it out (keep it in the oven long enough to leave no possibility of water remaining). The heat will stop the bismuth from pulling up, and allow it to fall into the mold better. Other than these things, you did an amazing job. I always look forward to watching your new uploads! Keep on being awesome!

Ah, you have ventured into the world of metallurgy with this project! Your observation that there is a temperature where the oxide breaks down is actually true for all metals! It is a thermodynamically controlled process that depends mainly on temperature and the partial pressure of oxygen. To visualize this relationship, graphs called Ellingham diagrams plot Temperature vs pressure. They can be rather confusing to read though. Anyway, great video IMO. Keep it up!

I've done this before based on your previous video, and I've got 2 things I think will help the yield:
1. the oxidized bismuth can be reprocessed by adding it back to HCl and using aluminum foil again, and
2. the initial low yield might be caused by some BiCl3 being hydrolyzed when the tablets are added to the acid, and some of that white precipitate of extra junk in the tablets could very well be BiOCl. I found that pouring conc. HCl over the white stuff in the filter gave a solution that had bismuth in it as well.


edit: a third thing (which I was reminded of by another comment) is to use borax as a flux when melting to prevent oxidation

Two things to try:
1) Now that you have some crystals, break off some with the pliers, and melt the rest back down in the spoon in the heating mantle. Remove the heat, then add the crystal and let it sit on top. Wait as before, then decant the still liquid metal.
2) if you run this experiment again, and get the bismuth paste, put it on the coffee-filter paper and put it in an oven to dry out. Remove, and smash with a hammer (or mortar and pestle), then add to a large test tube as before. Get some dry ice, and add to water to quickly form CO2 vapor; allow the vapor to spill over into the test tube, displacing the air, then stir the powder in the test tube to allow the CO2 to displace any remaining air & water vapor. Now heat as before to obtain the molten metal. This should avoid some of the problems you had before with the yellow oxide, and should increase the yield some. While the test tube is still hot, put it on a hot heating mantle (to avoid thermal shock to the thin glass), then remove the heat and allow to cool - when there’s only a little bit of liquid remaining, put in one of the saved crystals from this first experiment. This should work, unless bismuth is reactive towards CO2 at high temperature. 😎
